September 12, 2004: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.)
An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that
all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
WHITE HOT, by Sandra Brown. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) Returning home
after her brother's mysterious death, a woman is embroiled in family intrigue.
SKINNY DIP, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf, $24.95.) A woman enlists an ex-cop in a
plot to take revenge on her husband, a marine biologist who tried to kill her.
THE RULE OF FOUR, by Ian Caldwell and Dustin Thomason. (Dial, $24.) Two
Princeton students who are trying to unravel the mysteries of a Renaissance text
become ensnared in murderous intrigue.
ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Atria, $17.95.) A Harvard scholar tries to
save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society.
LOST CITY, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $26.95.) The
discovery of a life-prolonging enzyme -- 2,000 feet down in the Atlantic Ocean --
results in a series of disappearances and killings.
DARK JUSTICE, by Jack Higgins. (Putnam, $25.95.) Working with his British
counterpart, an American intelligence agent must uncover the source of an
international terror ring.
DUNE: The Battle of Corrin, by Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson. (Tor/Tom
Doherty, $27.95.) A prequel to Frank Herbert's science fiction series.
SAM'S LETTERS TO JENNIFER, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) In
the house where she grew up, a woman finds a collection of letters addressed to
her that will change her life forever.
THE WINDS OF CHANGE, by Martha Grimes. (Viking, $25.95.) Richard Jury and
Melrose Plant investigate the deaths of two little girls.
VISIONS IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $21.95.) In 2059, Lt. Eve Dallas
searches Manhattan for a killer; by Nora Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
BODY DOUBLE, by Tess Gerritsen. (Ballantine, $24.95.) A Boston medical
examiner is confronted with a murdered woman who looks exactly like her.
“R” IS FOR RICOCHET, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $26.95.) A
millionaire hires Kinsey Millhone to baby-sit his newly paroled daughter and keep
September 12, 2004
Non-Fiction
UNFIT FOR COMMAND, by John E. O'Neill and Jerome R. Corsi. (Regnery,
$27.95.) A negative appraisal of John Kerry's conduct in Vietnam.
AMERICAN SOLDIER, by Tommy Franks with Malcolm McConnell.
(ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $27.95.) A memoir by the former head of the United
States Central Command.
MY LIFE, by Bill Clinton. (Knopf, $35.) From Hope, Ark., to the White House: the
autobiography of the 42nd president.
BUSHWORLD, by Maureen Dowd. (Putnam, $25.95.) A journalist's assessment of
President Bush, based on her columns and articles in The New York Times.
EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $17.50.) An
Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks.
HOW TO MAKE LOVE LIKE A PORN STAR, by Jenna Jameson with Neil
Strauss. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $27.95.) A leading lady of adult movies
describes her unusual life and work.
DRESS YOUR FAMILY IN CORDUROY AND DENIM, by David Sedaris. (Little,
Brown, $24.95.) The humorist's latest collection of essays.
SKYWRITING, by Jane Pauley. (Random House, $25.95.) A memoir by the
television personality chronicles her career, family life and recent struggle with
bipolar disorder.
IMPERIAL HUBRIS, by Anonymous. (Brassey's, $27.50.) A current C.I.A. officer
argues that the United States and its allies are losing the war on terror.
SHADOW DIVERS, by Robert Kurson. (Random House, $26.95.) The story of a
group of divers who in 1991, 60 miles off the coast of New Jersey, discovered the
wreckage of a World War II-era German U-boat.
WHAT'S THE MATTER WITH KANSAS? by Thomas Frank. (Metropolitan/Holt,
$24.) An examination of what the author calls the Great Backlash, in which
conservatives "won the heart of America."
HIPPIE, by Barry Miles. (Sterling, $24.95.) A lavishly illustrated coffee-table book
celebrates the period from 1965 to 1971, the era of unparalleled tuning in, turning
on and dropping out.
NAMATH, by Mark Kriegel. (Viking, $27.95.) A biography of the renowned New
York Jets quarterback, advertising icon and man about town.
A MATTER OF CHARACTER, by Ronald Kessler. (Sentinel, $24.95.) A journalist's
admiring behind-the-scenes portrait of the Bush White House.
